1→# Self-Improvement Summary: 1770168330
     2→
     3→**Date:** 2026-02-03
     4→**Cycle:** First L2 introspection
     5→**Retrospectives reviewed:** 5 (1770156860, 1770160373, 1770161268, 1770163188, 1770165147)
     6→**MCP analysis tools queried:** 10
     7→
     8→---
     9→
    10→## Retrospectives Reviewed
    11→
    12→| Entry ID | Task | Key Observation |
    13→|----------|------|-----------------|
    14→| 1770156860 | Agent State Taxonomy (10 issues, 3 waves) | Zero corrections, 100% pre-offered option selection, user favors comprehensive scope |
    15→| 1770160373 | Sidebar Highlight Contrast | Doing mode detection failure -- user editing in VSCode, orchestrator spawned agent |
    16→| 1770161268 | Parallel Agent Config | Exemplary efficiency -- single directive covered all alignment |
    17→| 1770163188 | Sidebar Overhaul | Over-engineering toggle mechanism, two user redirections ("do not overcomplicate") |
    18→| 1770165147 | MCP Issue Logging + Multi-agent | MCP tool availability lag, 4-agent parallelism validated for config-only changes |
    19→
    20→---
    21→
    22→## Cross-Session Patterns
    23→
    24→### Pattern 1: User Communication Is Direct and Decisive
    25→
    26→Across all 5 sessions, the user answered alignment questions decisively with zero hesitation. In the taxonomy session, 13/15 questions used pre-offered options; 2 used "Other" when pre-offered options didn't capture a nuance. In the config session, a single directive sufficed for the entire task. The user consistently favors the most comprehensive/ambitious option and communicates at high velocity.
    27→
    28→**Implication:** Alignment questions are well-calibrated. The "Other" escape hatch works as designed. Verbosity in confirmations is friction, not thoroughness.
    29→
    30→### Pattern 2: Simplicity Signals Are Strong Directives
    31→
    32→In 2 of 5 sessions (40%), the user redirected Claude away from over-engineering. The pattern: user references an existing implementation -> Claude proposes alternatives -> user says "match the existing one." This is a systematic tendency, not a one-off.
    33→
    34→**Implication:** Claude's design exploration instinct conflicts with user's "match proven patterns" preference. This needs explicit counterprogramming in agent guidance.
    35→
    36→### Pattern 3: Agent Spawn Decision Needs Mode Awareness
    37→
    38→Session 1770160373 showed the orchestrator offering agent spawn when the user was in "doing mode" (editing directly in VSCode). The existing rule (3+ Bash calls) wasn't sufficient -- the user's mode was signaled by direct file edits, not bash commands.
    39→
    40→**Implication:** Doing mode detection needs richer signals beyond bash call count.
    41→
    42→### Pattern 4: System Infrastructure Works but Doesn't Observe Itself
    43→
    44→All 5 sessions had clean builds, clean gate checks, successful PR workflows, and atomic skill handoffs. The infrastructure is reliable. However, the observation layer (tags, quality scores) is broken -- tags don't discriminate and quality scores cover only 3% of entries. The system works but can't measure how well it works.
    45→
    46→---
    47→
    48→## Per-Pillar Synthesis
    49→
    50→### Pillar 1: User Effectiveness
    51→
    52→**L1 observations:** User communication is efficient, alignment questions work well, finalization can be faster. Doing mode detection failed once.
    53→
    54→**MCP findings:** 100% quick alignment (<=2 entries), 81 issue-driven vs 74 freeform tasks. No interruptions in 84/85 sessions.
    55→
    56→**Synthesis:** The user-facing interaction model is mature. The remaining friction is at the margins: verbose finalization confirmations and a single doing mode detection failure. Two issues logged (#113 doing mode, #116 verbose finalization).
    57→
    58→### Pillar 2: Claude Execution
    59→
    60→**L1 observations:** 100% plan approval rate, zero backward transitions. One session (taxonomy) executed 13 commits across 3 waves with zero regressions. Execution quality is high when aligned.
    61→
    62→**MCP findings:** 85% task completion rate. Finalization is the most common failure substate. 2 planning phases skipped.
    63→
    64→**Synthesis:** Execution quality is strong but completion rate has room to improve. The 15% incompletion likely stems from context compaction in long sessions disrupting the finalization ceremony. One investigation issue logged (#114).
    65→
    66→### Pillar 3: Alignment Patterns
    67→
    68→**L1 observations:** Over-engineering in 2/5 sessions when user had clear pattern reference. 100% plan approval on first presentation.
    69→
    70→**MCP findings:** 29/29 plans reached execution (100% approval). Zero backward transitions.
    71→
    72→**Synthesis:** Alignment succeeds structurally (plans always approved) but Claude's tendency to explore design space creates friction when the user wants simplicity ma

1→# Self-Improvement Summary: 1770174872
     2→
     3→**Date:** 2026-02-03
     4→**Cycle:** Second L2 introspection
     5→**Retrospectives reviewed:** 2 (1770170870, 1770174216)
     6→**MCP analysis tools queried:** 12 (1 broken: sbs_question_stats)
     7→
     8→---
     9→
    10→## Retrospectives Reviewed
    11→
    12→| Entry ID | Task | Key Observation |
    13→|----------|------|-----------------|
    14→| 1770170870 | MVP expansion (#68, #109) -- 4 waves, 8 agents | Exploration redundancy (4 agents confirming same CSS), dead code detection gap (renderBadge never called) |
    15→| 1770174216 | Backlog triage -- 14 issues, 3 waves, 6 agents | MCP module caching divergence, compressed finalization validated, triage wave structure effective |
    16→
    17→---
    18→
    19→## Previous Cycle Follow-Up
    20→
    21→| Issue | Status | Outcome |
    22→|-------|--------|---------|
    23→| #110 (tag discrimination) | Closed | Per-session scoping added, but tag analysis still shows 0 signal. Root problem unresolved. |
    24→| #111 (quality scores 3.2%) | Open | Investigated during triage, deferred -- needs build-time integration |
    25→| #112 (simplicity-matching) | Closed | Guidance added. No over-engineering in 2 subsequent sessions. |
    26→| #113 (doing mode detection) | Closed | Detection rules expanded |
    27→| #114 (task incompletion 15%) | Open | Task completion now 85.7% (up from 85%) |
    28→| #115 (T6 threshold) | Closed | Threshold corrected from 0.95 to 0.90 |
    29→| #116 (verbose finalization) | Closed | Compressed finalization implemented and immediately validated |
    30→
    31→**Closure rate:** 5/7 (71%). Two remaining issues (#111, #114) are investigations requiring deeper work.
    32→
    33→---
    34→
    35→## Cross-Session Patterns
    36→
    37→### Pattern 1: Observation Layer Remains the Weakest Link
    38→
    39→Despite closing #110, the tag system still produces zero discriminatory signal. All 83 tags have signal_score 0.0. The per-session scoping fix prevented cross-session leakage but didn't address the fundamental problem: rules fire uniformly across all sessions. Quality score coverage remains at 3.2%. The system works reliably but cannot measure how well it works. This was the top finding in L2 cycle 1 and remains the top finding in cycle 2.
    40→
    41→**Trend:** Persistent. Two cycles, same core issue. #121 reopens this with a focus on rule discrimination rather than scope leakage.
    42→
    43→### Pattern 2: Parallel Agent Coordination Maturing but Has Blind Spots
    44→
    45→The MVP session (8 agents, 4 waves) and triage session (6 agents, 3 waves) both executed cleanly with zero file collisions and no backward transitions. Parallelism mechanics are solid. However, exploration-phase parallelism has a quality gap: multiple agents independently confirm the same fact instead of dividing investigation dimensions.
    46→
    47→**Trend:** New finding. Not visible in cycle 1 because previous sessions used fewer exploration agents.
    48→
    49→### Pattern 3: Tool Trust Requires Qualification
    50→
    51→The MCP module caching issue (retrospective 1770174216) introduced a new category of system friction: tool output diverging from ground truth due to stale process state. This is distinct from previous tool issues (missing capabilities, wrong thresholds) -- it's a reliability hazard where the tool appears to work but returns stale data.
    52→
    53→**Trend:** New finding. Specific to sessions where Python source is edited and then validated via MCP.
    54→
    55→### Pattern 4: Meta-Recursion Accelerates Improvement
    56→
    57→The triage session (#120) implemented fixes from the previous self-improve cycle (#112, #113, #115, #116) and immediately validated two of them within the same session. #116 (compressed finalization) was used successfully at the session's end. This demonstrates a healthy feedback loop where self-improve findings translate to actionable fixes that are exercised in subsequent sessions.
    58→
    59→---
    60→
    61→## Per-Pillar Synthesis
    62→
    63→### Pillar 1: User Effectiveness
    64→
    65→**L1 observations:** User continues to be decisive and efficient. Compressed finalization (#116) validated. Triage alignment: 0.2 questions per issue. Visual review during planning surfaces concrete requirements.
    66→
    67→**MCP findings:** 100% quick alignment (<=2 entries). 85 issue-driven, 78 freeform tasks. 1 interruption in 90 sessions.
    68→
    69→**Synthesis:** User interaction is stable and efficient. The main improvement opportunity is structural: documenting triage wave patterns (#127) so future sessions benefit from the efficient structure observed in 1770174216. No regressions from cycle 1.
    70→
    71→### Pillar 2: Claude Execution
    72→
    73→**L1 observations:** Exploration redundancy (4 agents on same question). Dead code missed by surface-level checks. Feature removal requires

1→# Self-Improvement Summary: 1770183546
     2→
     3→**Date:** 2026-02-04
     4→**Cycle:** Third L2 introspection
     5→**Retrospectives reviewed:** 3 (1770178263, 1770180967, 1770182650)
     6→**MCP analysis tools queried:** 13 (all functional, including previously broken sbs_question_stats)
     7→
     8→---
     9→
    10→## Retrospectives Reviewed
    11→
    12→| Entry ID | Task | Key Observation |
    13→|----------|------|-----------------|
    14→| 1770178263 | MVP Test Suite Expansion (#119) -- 102 new tests, 3 waves | 2 plan rejections from not reading Known Limitations (Verso pages), 13 test failures from undocumented ID normalization assumptions |
    15→| 1770180967 | Batch Issue Crush (10 issues) -- 5 waves, 7 agents, 0 retries | Cleanest session to date. Triage-by-actionability compressed alignment to 3 questions. Zero user interventions during execution. |
    16→| 1770182650 | /task #133 #134 -- 2 parallel agents, 0 retries | Dual archive write paths created (full pipeline vs direct JSONL). Taxonomy test coupling flagged as recurring maintenance. |
    17→
    18→---
    19→
    20→## Previous Cycle Follow-Up
    21→
    22→| Issue | Status | Outcome |
    23→|-------|--------|---------|
    24→| #121 (tag discrimination) | Closed | Rules redesigned, but ALL tags still signal_score 0.0. Third cycle with same result. Approach deferred to DuckDB (#118, #138). |
    25→| #122 (exploration differentiation) | Closed | Guidance added. Not directly tested in subsequent sessions (no multi-agent exploration in the 3 sessions reviewed). |
    26→| #123 (MCP module caching) | Closed | Fixed with importlib.reload(). No recurrence in subsequent sessions. |
    27→| #124 (call-chain tracing) | Closed | Guidance added. Dead code detection not tested in subsequent sessions. |
    28→| #125 (test cleanup on removal) | Closed | Guidance added. No feature removals in subsequent sessions to validate. |
    29→| #126 (question_stats datetime) | Closed | Fixed. Tool now returns 544 questions across 81 sessions. Fully functional. |
    30→| #127 (triage wave structure) | Closed | Guidance added and immediately validated in crush session (1770180967). |
    31→
    32→**Closure rate:** 7/7 (100%, up from 71% in cycle 1).
    33→
    34→**Key finding:** High closure rate does not guarantee metric improvement. #121 and #111 were closed but their target metrics (tag discrimination, quality coverage) show zero improvement. Issue closure tracked code changes; downstream metric verification was missing.
    35→
    36→---
    37→
    38→## Cross-Session Patterns
    39→
    40→### Pattern 1: Issue Closure != Problem Resolution
    41→
    42→The most important meta-observation of this cycle. Both persistent findings (tags, quality scores) had issues closed in the crush session, but the underlying metrics didn't change. The crush session closed #121 with rule redesign and #111 with investigation findings, but:
    43→- Tags: Still ALL at signal_score 0.0 (3rd consecutive cycle)
    44→- Quality coverage: Still at 3.1% (3rd consecutive cycle)
    45→
    46→**Root cause:** Issues were closed based on code changes expected to fix the problem. No verification step confirmed the metric actually improved post-closure. This is a systemic gap in the issue lifecycle.
    47→
    48→**Action taken:** For tags, deferred to DuckDB (#118, #138). For quality scores, proposed build pipeline integration (#143) instead of standalone tooling.
    49→
    50→### Pattern 2: Execution Quality Continues to Improve
    51→
    52→The crush session (10 issues, 5 waves, 7 agents, 0 retries) is the cleanest execution observed. Combined with the #133/#134 session (2 issues, parallel agents, 0 retries), execution quality is trending strongly positive:
    53→- Task completion: 85% -> 85.7% -> 86.7%
    54→- Backward transitions: 0 (stable across all 3 cycles)
    55→- Gate failures: 0/26 (stable)
    56→- Plan approval: 31/31 (100%)
    57→
    58→The exploration-then-plan pattern is now validated across multiple session types (single-issue, multi-issue crush, feature implementation).
    59→
    60→### Pattern 3: Known Documentation Not Consulted
    61→
    62→The MVP session (retrospective 1770178263) revealed a new failure mode: agents not consulting existing documentation before planning/executing. Two instances:
    63→1. Known Limitations (Verso pages removed) -- in CLAUDE.md, not read before planning
    64→2. ID Normalization rules -- in sbs-developer.md, not applied during test writing
    65→
    66→This is distinct from the "simplicity matching" pattern identified in cycle 1. That was about design preference; this is about factual constraints that are documented but not consulted. Two new issues (#136, #137) address this.
    67→
    68→### Pattern 4: Observation Layer Debt Is Structural, Not Incremental
    69→
    70→Three cycles of incremental fixes to the observation layer (tags, quality scores) have produced zero impro

1→# Self-Improvement Summary: 1770188864
     2→
     3→**Date:** 2026-02-04
     4→**Cycle:** Fourth L2 introspection
     5→**Retrospectives reviewed:** 2 (1770185443, 1770188134)
     6→**Improvement captures reviewed:** 2 (1770184492, 1770187075)
     7→**MCP analysis tools queried:** 11 (all functional)
     8→
     9→---
    10→
    11→## Retrospectives Reviewed
    12→
    13→| Entry ID | Task | Key Observation |
    14→|----------|------|-----------------|
    15→| 1770185443 | /task #144 (QA skill + browser tools) | Exploration-before-questions principle crystallized: agent asked about Chrome MCP instead of checking .mcp.json. User explicitly corrected. 2 parallel agents, zero retries. |
    16→| 1770188134 | /task crush (7 issues: #136-141, #147) | Cleanest crush session yet. 4 agents across 2 waves, zero retries, zero corrections. Documentation-first wave ordering validated. |
    17→
    18→## Improvement Captures Reviewed
    19→
    20→| Entry ID | Category | Observation |
    21→|----------|----------|-------------|
    22→| 1770184492 | interaction | Exploration should precede user questions during alignment. Check config/state before asking. |
    23→| 1770187075 | tooling | sbs_serve_project returns {running: false} without error details. QA skill needed manual fallback. |
    24→
    25→---
    26→
    27→## Previous Cycle Follow-Up
    28→
    29→| Issue | Status | Outcome |
    30→|-------|--------|---------|
    31→| #136 (pre-flight checklist) | Closed (crush) | Guidance added to SKILL.md. No post-closure /task session to verify yet. |
    32→| #137 (consult docs before coding) | Closed (crush) | Guidance added to sbs-developer.md. No post-closure session to verify. |
    33→| #138 (defer auto-tagger to DuckDB) | Closed (crush) | Policy decision. Tags still 0.0 signal score; DuckDB path acknowledged. |
    34→| #139 (quantitative success criteria) | Closed (crush) | Guidance added. No post-closure session to verify. |
    35→| #140 (taxonomy test reminder) | Closed (crush) | Guidance added. No post-closure session to verify. |
    36→| #141 (self-improve entry search fix) | Closed (crush) | Code fix applied. Tool now returns correct entries. |
    37→| #143 (quality validators in build.py) | Still open | Quality coverage still 3.1%. 4th cycle unchanged. |
    38→| #142 (e2e test for improvement_capture) | Still open | Tool actively used (2 captures between cycles), but no formal test. |
    39→
    40→**Closure rate for cycle 3 issues:** 6/8 closed (75%). 2 remaining (#142, #143) are implementation work, not guidance updates.
    41→
    42→**Key finding:** 6 of 8 issues from the previous cycle were guidance additions closed in a single crush session. These are easy to close but hard to verify -- they require subsequent sessions to demonstrate behavioral change. None of the 6 have been verified yet because the crush session was the most recent /task invocation.
    43→
    44→---
    45→
    46→## Cross-Session Patterns
    47→
    48→### Pattern 1: Guidance Additions Accumulate Without Verification
    49→
    50→Cycles 2-4 have produced 14 guidance additions to SKILL.md and agent files. Only 2 have been verified (the crush triage pattern from #127, and the exploration-then-plan pattern from general observation). The rest are assumed effective because they were closed.
    51→
    52→This is the same "closure != resolution" pattern identified in cycle 3, but applied to process guidance rather than metrics. Adding words to a SKILL.md doesn't guarantee agents read and follow them -- the same failure mode that prompted #136 (agents not reading Known Limitations).
    53→
    54→### Pattern 2: Improvement Captures Are Working
    55→
    56→Two `sbs_improvement_capture` entries were created between cycles, both containing actionable observations that fed directly into this cycle's findings. This validates the zero-friction capture workflow introduced in cycle 3. The tool is being used as intended.
    57→
    58→### Pattern 3: Execution Quality Continues Upward Trend
    59→
    60→| Metric | Cycle 2 | Cycle 3 | Cycle 4 |
    61→|--------|---------|---------|---------|
    62→| Task completion | 85.7% | 86.7% | 87.2% |
    63→| Backward transitions | 0 | 0 | 0 |
    64→| Gate failures | 0/22 | 0/26 | 0/26 |
    65→| Plan approval | 100% | 100% | 100% |
    66→| Interruption rate | 1/97 | 2/103 | 2/103 |
    67→
    68→The crush session (#7 issues, 4 agents, 0 retries) and QA skill session (#144, 2 agents, 0 retries) both show clean execution. The process is maturing.
    69→
    70→### Pattern 4: Persistent Metrics Remain Unmoved
    71→
    72→Quality score coverage: 3.1% (cycles 1-4, unchanged). Tag signal scores: 0.0 (cycles 1-4, unchanged). Both have been acknowledged as architectural problems requiring structural solutions (#143 for quality, DuckDB for tags). Until those are implemented, these metrics will remain static.
    73→
    74→---
    75→
    76→## Per-Pillar Synthesis

1→# Self-Improvement Summary: 1770194370
     2→
     3→**Date:** 2026-02-04
     4→**Cycle:** Fifth L2 introspection
     5→**Retrospectives reviewed:** 2 (1770192056, 1770193776)
     6→**Improvement captures reviewed:** 1 (1770193719)
     7→**MCP analysis tools queried:** 11 (all functional)
     8→
     9→---
    10→
    11→## Retrospectives Reviewed
    12→
    13→| Entry ID | Task | Key Observation |
    14→|----------|------|-----------------|
    15→| 1770192056 | /task #155 (wall-clock time optimization) | 8 agents, 3 waves, 856 lines, zero collisions. Auto-tagger flagged clean execution as problematic. Alignment was efficient due to orthogonal questions. |
    16→| 1770193776 | /task crush (8 issues: #156, #153, #154, #152, #150, #142, #146, #143) | Fastest alignment ever for multi-issue task. IO shorthand adopted immediately. `gh` CLI repo inference bug observed. Test simulation anti-pattern identified. |
    17→
    18→## Improvement Captures Reviewed
    19→
    20→| Entry ID | Category | Observation |
    21→|----------|----------|-------------|
    22→| 1770193719 | tooling | MCP repo tests require project-specific venv; sbs_run_tests can't reach them. |
    23→
    24→---
    25→
    26→## Previous Cycle Follow-Up
    27→
    28→| Issue | Status | Outcome |
    29→|-------|--------|---------|
    30→| #152 (explore-before-ask) | Closed (crush) | Guidance added to sbs-developer.md. Not yet verified in practice. |
    31→| #153 (serve tool errors) | Closed (crush) | Error field added to ServeResult. Not yet verified via /qa. |
    32→| #154 (metric verification in finalization) | Closed (crush) | Runtime state checks added to SKILL.md. Not yet verified. |
    33→| #142 (e2e test for improvement_capture) | Closed (crush) | 5 tests added, but retrospective notes they are simulation tests, not integration. |
    34→| #143 (quality validators in build.py) | Closed (crush) | Quality validator integration added. No build run since to verify coverage improvement. |
    35→
    36→**Closure rate for cycle 4 issues:** 5/5 remaining issues all closed (100% cumulative). However, 0/5 have been verified in subsequent sessions.
    37→
    38→**Key finding:** The crush session cleared the entire backlog from cycle 4, but verification remains pending for all items. This extends the guidance verification debt pattern identified in cycle 4.
    39→
    40→---
    41→
    42→## Cross-Session Patterns
    43→
    44→### Pattern 1: Auto-Tag Uniformity Within Sessions
    45→
    46→All 197 v2-era entries carry the same ~20 tags because the auto-tagger computes from session-level metadata (token counts, tool distribution, model). Tags like `signal:retry-loop` appear on clean execution entries because they describe the session aggregate. This has been true for multiple cycles but this is the first time a retrospective explicitly flagged it as misleading ("over-sensitive to normal exploration patterns").
    47→
    48→The tag system currently serves as a session classifier, not an entry classifier. This distinction hasn't been articulated before.
    49→
    50→### Pattern 2: Crush Mode is a Mature, Reliable Pattern
    51→
    52→Two consecutive sessions (#155 feature task, then crush) both executed cleanly with no retries, no collisions, and 100% plan approval. The crush specifically: 8 issues, 5 waves, 8 agents, 0 corrections. The triage-table presentation format enables fast approval. Crush mode has crossed from "experimental" to "standard operating procedure."
    53→
    54→### Pattern 3: Guidance Verification Debt is Compounding
    55→
    56→| Cycle | Guidance additions | Verified |
    57→|-------|-------------------|----------|
    58→| 2 | ~5 | 2 |
    59→| 3 | ~5 | 0 |
    60→| 4 | 3 | 0 |
    61→| 5 (crush closures) | 8 | 0 |
    62→| **Total** | **~21** | **2** |
    63→
    64→This is the most concerning cross-session pattern. 90%+ of guidance additions remain unverified. The self-improve cycle creates recommendations, which get closed via code/doc changes, but there's no feedback loop confirming behavioral change. Issue #164 addresses this.
    65→
    66→### Pattern 4: Execution Metrics Continue Stable
    67→
    68→| Metric | Cycle 3 | Cycle 4 | Cycle 5 |
    69→|--------|---------|---------|---------|
    70→| Task completion | 86.7% | 87.2% | 87.8% |
    71→| Backward transitions | 0 | 0 | 0 |
    72→| Gate failures | 0/26 | 0/26 | 0/28 |
    73→| Plan approval | 100% | 100% | 100% |
    74→| Interruption rate | 2/103 | 2/103 | 2/109 |
    75→
    76→All operational metrics are stable or improving slightly. The system is in steady state for execution quality.
    77→
    78→---
    79→
    80→## Per-Pillar Synthesis
    81→
    82→### Pillar 1: User Effectiveness
    83→
    84→**L1 observations:** User continues efficient and decisive. Task #155: 5 orthogonal questions, all answered immediately. Crush: single triage proposal, instant approval. IO shorthand adopted within minutes of docu

todos.content: Synthesize L3 meta-analysis across all 7 dimensions

tool_calls.result_content: Todos have been modified successfully. Ensure that you continue to use the todo list to track your progress. Please proceed with the current tasks if applicable

1→# Meta-Improvement Analysis: L3-1770195056
     2→
     3→**Level:** 3
     4→**Date:** 2026-02-04
     5→**L2 Documents Analyzed:** 5 (1770168330, 1770174872, 1770183546, 1770188864, 1770194370)
     6→**Date Range:** 2026-02-03 to 2026-02-04
     7→
     8→---
     9→
    10→## 1. Skill Evolution Trajectory
    11→
    12→The self-improvement system has undergone a measurable maturation across 5 cycles in roughly 30 hours. Tracking four dimensions reveals where the system is strengthening and where it is plateauing.
    13→
    14→### Finding Categories: Surface to Meta
    15→
    16→| Cycle | L2 Entry | Finding Nature | Example |
    17→|-------|----------|----------------|---------|
    18→| 1 | 1770168330 | Surface-level discovery | "We can't measure X" (#110, #111), "User is decisive" |
    19→| 2 | 1770174872 | Refinement | "Fix for #110 didn't go far enough" (#121), "Exploration agents duplicate work" (#122) |
    20→| 3 | 1770183546 | Architectural recognition | "Incremental tag fixes are futile" (#138), "Issue closure != problem resolution" |
    21→| 4 | 1770188864 | Meta-process | "Guidance additions accumulate without verification" (#154), "Metric verification in finalization" |
    22→| 5 | 1770194370 | Meta-process + precision | "Verification protocol" (#164), "Test simulation anti-pattern" (#162), "Tags are session-level not entry-level" (#160) |
    23→
    24→The trajectory is clear: the system moved from identifying what is broken (cycle 1), to refining fixes that didn't work (cycle 2), to recognizing that the fix strategy itself was wrong (cycle 3), to questioning whether its own improvement feedback loop is functional (cycles 4-5). This is genuine meta-cognitive maturation, not just iteration.
    25→
    26→### Finding Depth vs. Finding Count
    27→
    28→| Cycle | Findings Logged | Nature |
    29→|-------|----------------|--------|
    30→| 1 | 7 | Broad surface sweep |
    31→| 2 | 7 | Targeted refinements |
    32→| 3 | 8 | Deepest single-cycle output |
    33→| 4 | 3 | Fewer but deeper |
    34→| 5 | 5 | Meta-process + precision |
    35→
    36→Total: 30 issues logged across 5 cycles. The count peaked at cycle 3 then declined, while depth increased. This is the classic pattern of a system transitioning from problem discovery to problem understanding. The system is not running out of things to find; it is finding fewer, harder things.
    37→
    38→### Closure vs. Verification: The Central Tension
    39→
    40→| Cycle | Issues from previous cycle | Closed | Verified |
    41→|-------|---------------------------|--------|----------|
    42→| 2 | 7 from cycle 1 | 5 (71%) | 2 |
    43→| 3 | 7 from cycle 2 | 7 (100%) | ~0 (metric targets unchanged) |
    44→| 4 | 8 from cycle 3 | 6 (75%) | 0 |
    45→| 5 | 3+2 from cycle 4 | 5 (100%) | 0 |
    46→
    47→The closure pipeline accelerated from 71% to 100%. The verification pipeline never started. This is the single most important structural finding across all 5 L2 documents: the system has optimized for closing issues while leaving verification as an afterthought. Cycle 3 was the first to name this explicitly ("Issue closure != problem resolution"). Cycle 4 formalized it. Cycle 5 logged a protocol for it (#164). But as of the final cycle, zero guidance additions from cycles 3-5 have been verified in practice.
    48→
    49→### Is the System Maturing or Plateauing?
    50→
    51→Both. Execution metrics show steady improvement (task completion 85% to 87.8%). Finding quality shows genuine deepening. But the system's ability to verify its own improvements is stalled -- it has identified the verification gap in 3 consecutive cycles without closing it. The system is maturing in what it observes but plateauing in its ability to act on observations about itself.
    52→
    53→---
    54→
    55→## 2. Recurring Friction Inventory
    56→
    57→Three problems appear in 3+ L2 summaries despite being "addressed." Their persistence is diagnostic.
    58→
    59→### Auto-Tag Signal Uniformity
    60→
    61→| Cycle | Status | Signal Score | Action Taken |
    62→|-------|--------|-------------|--------------|
    63→| 1 | Identified (#110) | 0.0 | Issue logged |
    64→| 2 | Fix attempted (#121) | 0.0 | Per-session scoping added; didn't help |
    65→| 3 | Architectural redirect (#138) | 0.0 | Deferred to DuckDB (#118) |
    66→| 4 | Acknowledged as structural | 0.0 | No new action |
    67→| 5 | Reclassified (#160) | 0.0 | Session-level vs entry-level distinction articulated |
    68→
    69→**Appearances:** 5/5 cycles. Zero metric improvement.
    70→
    71→**Diagnosis:** The tag system was designed with a flawed assumption: that session-level metadata (token counts, tool distributions, model versions) would produce entry-level discrimination. It cannot, by construction. Five cycles of attempted fixes produced zero signal improvement because the architecture is wrong, not the implementation. Cycle 3 recognized this and redirected
